name: Acoustic Rock
description: Rock with acoustic instrumentation, as opposed to the typical electric instrumentation.

name: Afro-Rock
description: Incorporates West African influences; initially emerged in the early 1970s.

name: Alternative Rock
description: Consists of verse-chorus song structures performed with a less commercial sensibility, pairing Pop songwriting with more eccentric, Punk-influenced sounds, moodier or quirkier lyricism, and sometimes ample amounts of distortion and fuzz.

children.name: Alternative Dance
children.description: Incorporates rhythms and synthesizers from Electronic Dance Music within the context of Alternative Rock and related styles; predominantly popular in the 1990s.

children.name: Grebo
children.description: Short-lived English subculture and associated music; raw, futuristic, sample-heavy form of Alternative Dance with a grungy guitar sound.

children.name: New Rave
children.description: High energy mid-2000s form of Alternative Dance that combines Dance-Punk with elements of Electronic Dance Music styles like Electroclash and Electro House.

children.name: Baggy
children.description: Psychedelic, dance-inflected Alternative Rock from the late 1980s that was initially associated with Manchester in northern England and later connected to the "baggy" fashion style that became popular across the country.

children.name: Britpop
children.description: Emerged in the United Kingdom in the early 1990s, with a style hearkening back to the traditional guitar-driven songs and melodic hooks found in the British Pop Rock of the 1960s.

children.name: Dream Pop
children.description: Characterized by reverberated guitars, effects-laden vocals, and dense productions, creating a psychedelic, spacious, and dreamlike sound.

children.name: Emo-Pop
children.description: Mainstream derivative of Emo, puts more emphasis on the poppy sensibilities of Alternative Rock and Pop Punk.

children.name: Geek Rock
children.description: Emphasizes a nerdy aesthetic, incorporating synthesizers and other instrumentation less common in Alternative Rock alongside quirky Pop-oriented songwriting and dense, witty lyricism on unconventional topics.

children.name: Grunge
children.description: Characterized by a mid-tempo approach featuring a heavy 'sludgy' guitar-sound, 'raspy vocals', and angsty lyricism; noted for its mixture of Punk and Metal sensibilites, among several other influences.

children.name: Indie Rock
children.description: Associated with a less mainstream-oriented and a DIY approach while often dabbling in Pop-informed melodic songwriting, eclecticism, and adopting an "authentic" or raw style.

children.name: C86
children.description: Distinctly ramshackle, often Twee Pop-infused combination of British Indie Rock and Jangle Pop.

children.name: Dunedin Sound
children.description: Emerged in Dunedin, New Zealand in the early 1980s, featuring a murky, lo-fi sound that overlaps with contemporaneous Jangle Pop and Slacker Rock styles.

children.name: Garage Rock Revival
children.description: Incorporated the raucous spirit of '60s Garage Rock into the sensibilities of Alternative Rock and Indie Rock; predominant in the '00s.

children.name: Hamburger Schule
children.description: Combines traditions of the Neue Deutsche Welle based on Grunge with Pop-hooks and elements of Indie Rock and Punk Rock.

children.name: Indie Surf
children.description: Reverb-drenched, nostalgic, and often lo-fi, with influences from Surf Rock and Vocal Surf; rose to popularity around 2009.

children.name: Math Pop
children.description: Energetic Indie Rock which incorporates poppier melodies and song structures into the unconventional rhythmic patterns of Math Rock.

children.name: Midwest Emo
children.description: Features the emotional and melodic style of Emo that usually alternates between loud and soft dynamics; off-key, strained vocals with little screaming; and arpeggiated guitar parts.

children.name: New Rave
children.description: High energy mid-2000s form of Alternative Dance that combines Dance-Punk with elements of Electronic Dance Music styles like Electroclash and Electro House.

children.name: Noise Pop
children.description: Arose in the mid-1980s; blend of poppier Rock songwriting and melodies with the dissonant, noisy timbres of distorted guitars and frequent use of guitar feedback.

children.name: Post-Punk Revival
children.description: Incorporating the sounds and aesthetics of Post-Punk into Indie Rock, with jagged guitarwork, a dominant and danceable rhythm section, clean production, and poppy song structures.

children.name: Slacker Rock
children.description: Raw, noisy, melodic Indie Rock, with a loose, blasé approach to performances, and typically low-fidelity production, associated with Generation X "slacker" culture.

children.name: Shitgaze
children.description: Extremely raw and lo-fi, blending raucous Garage Rock with the abrasive, often dissonant guitars of Noise Rock to create a sonic wall of deafening distortion inspired by Shoegaze.

children.name: Slowcore
children.description: Characterized by its subdued, often sombre songwriting and slow tempos, while taking primarily from genres like Dream Pop and Folk Rock.

children.name: Twee Pop
children.description: Distinct Post-Punk background and often jangling guitars, defined by a cute aesthetic and lyrics combined with an indie/DIY attitude and a simplicity often indebted to Punk Rock.

children.name: Jangle Pop
children.description: Pop-oriented songwriting based around chiming jangly guitar lines, and propulsive rhythms often drawn from Post-Punk.

children.name: C86
children.description: Distinctly ramshackle, often Twee Pop-infused combination of British Indie Rock and Jangle Pop.

children.name: Neo-Acoustic
children.description: Japanese term for a cross-section of Indie Pop and Jangle Pop with more prominent acoustic instrumentation and songwriting/arrangements that draw from Sophisti-Pop.

children.name: Paisley Underground
children.description: Emerged in Los Angeles in the early 1980s, featuring the energy of Power Pop and New Wave adorned with retro Psychedelia.

children.name: J-Rock
children.description: Japanese style that grew out of the Shimokitazawa indie scene, featuring Pop-informed songwriting, melodic guitar leads, expressive vocals, and often loud, prominent overdriven guitars.

children.name: Post-Britpop
children.description: Emerged in the late 1990s as a Britpop expansion mainly characterized by acoustic-leaning instrumentation, lush string arrangements, and mid-tempo song structures, as well as less apparent lyrical concerns for Britain in favor of introspective, contemplative themes.

children.name: Post-Grunge
children.description: Derivative of Grunge that emerged in the mid-1990s with emphasis on catchier hooks and more conventional song structures.

children.name: Shoegaze
children.description: Characterized by ethereal, noisy washes of sound created by extensive usage of multiple effect pedals, such as distortion, reverb, and delay; dreamy, usually unintelligible vocals, and roaring volumes.

name: Anatolian Rock
description: Turkish Rock with elements of Turkish Folk Music.

name: AOR
description: Emerged in the late 1970s and early 1980s as an amalgamation of Hard Rock, Pop Rock, and Progressive Rock; characterized by a rich, layered sound, slick production and a heavy reliance on commercial melodic hooks.

name: Art Punk
description: Combines the stripped-down aggression of rudimentary Punk Rock with frequent experimentation ranging from instrumental interplay, noise, dissonance, and/or influences from other genres such as Jazz or Funk.

children.name: Egg Punk
children.description: Originated in the early 2010s; features lo-fi production, eccentric lyrics, quick tempos, nasally vocals, and cheap keyboard sounds.

name: Art Rock
description: Attempts to expand the bounds of Rock within conventional structures, often using outside influences or experimentation for conceptual or thematic purpose.

name: Bard Rock
description: Mixes Rock music and styles with Avtorskaya pesnya.

name: Blues Rock
description: Relies on the chords/scales and instrumental improvisation of Blues.

children.name: Boogie Rock
children.description: Southern-influenced American Blues Rock that emphasizes a straightforward groove-oriented sound, rather than the instrumental experimentation found in more progressive and psychedelic blues rock bands.

name: British Rhythm & Blues
description: A style infusing Rock and R&B that was hugely popular in the United Kingdom between 1963 and 1966.

name: Candombe beat
description: Fusion of Uruguayan Candombe with elements of Rock music.

name: Christian Rock
description: Incorporates Christian lyrics, with topics such as faith, metaphysics, or biblical characters.

name: Comedy Rock
description: Roughly defined as a mix of Rock or any of its subgenres with elements of Comedy such as Satire and Musical Parody, as well as concepts of Novelty.

name: Country Rock
description: Combination of contemporary Rock with more traditional American Country.

name: Cowpunk
description: Mixes together Country Rock, Rockabilly, and Contemporary Folk with the familiar punk sound.

name: Deutschrock
description: Lyrics address German life, culture, and identity wrapped in upbeat songs, anthemic ballads, and a strong focus on the personality of the lead singer.

name: Emo
description: Focuses on emotional lyrics, expressive vocals, melodic songwriting, and dynamic song structures.

children.name: Emocore
children.description: Emerged primarily in Washington D.C. in 1985 as a reaction to the stagnant Hardcore Punk scene, with a less aggressive style that was more melodic and often featured emotional, introspective lyrics.

children.name: Emo-Pop
children.description: Mainstream derivative of Emo, puts more emphasis on the poppy sensibilities of Alternative Rock and Pop Punk.

children.name: Midwest Emo
children.description: Features the emotional and melodic style of Emo that usually alternates between loud and soft dynamics; off-key, strained vocals with little screaming; and arpeggiated guitar parts.

children.name: Screamo
children.description: Began in the early 1990s, merging the emotional lyrics and melodicism of Emo with the intensity, aggression and speed of Hardcore Punk.

children.name: Emoviolence
children.description: Volatile, aggressive sound of Screamo with slight Powerviolence undertones.

name: Experimental Rock
description: Eschews accessibility and convention, experimenting with song structures, time signatures, rhythm, dissonance, instrumentation, noise, electronics, studio manipulation, and other techniques not traditionally associated with Rock.

children.name: Avant-Prog
children.description: Focuses on highly complex, dense arrangements often featuring high amounts of dissonance and uncommon time signatures, sometimes extending towards atonality, free time, Free Improvisation, and other avant-garde techniques.

children.name: Brutal Prog
children.description: Characterized by highly intense and visceral songwriting, usually featuring substantial reliance on dissonance, odd time signatures, blistering tempos, angular and mercurial rhythms, and Punk's DIY attitude.

children.name: Rock in Opposition
children.description: European, complex Avant-Prog from the 1970s, so named due to the artists' opposition to the music industry.

children.name: Zeuhl
children.description: Epic, operatic sound fusing Jazz, Progressive Rock and Modern Classical music.

children.name: Krautrock
children.description: Brings together Psychedelic Rock, avant-garde composition, and other eclectic sources, while dissociating itself from Rock's Rhythm & Blues influences.

children.name: No Wave
children.description: Emerged in New York City during the late 1970s; took the ethos of Punk Rock but discarded melody and catchiness, including instead extreme noise, distortion, feedback, angular rhythms, stream-of-consciousness lyrics, and more.

name: Folk Rock
description: Influenced by Folk, particularly in the use of acoustic instrumentation and relatively simple arrangements; has its origins in the American Contemporary Folk movement of the 1960s.

children.name: Alpenrock
children.description: Mixes Hard Rock and Blues Rock with traditional Alpine Folk Music elements such as Yodeling and use of the accordion.

children.name: British Folk Rock
children.description: Developed in the late 1960s; influenced by traditional British folk music, particularly English Folk Music.

children.name: Celtic Rock
children.description: Incorporates influences from Celtic Folk Music and its regional variants.

children.name: Mittelalter-Rock
children.description: Emerged in the 1990s from the German Neo-Medieval movement, incorporating medieval instruments with Rock music.

children.name: Nordic Folk Rock
children.description: Fusion of Nordic Folk Music and Rock.

children.name: Phleng phuea chiwit
children.description: Political Thai Folk Rock born out of the 1973 student uprising, with a name translating to "songs for life".

children.name: Pinoy Folk Rock
children.description: Typically sung in Tagalog and pioneered in the 1970s, incorporating elements of indigenous music such as Kulintang gong music and the kubing bamboo jaw harp.

children.name: Rock rural
children.description: Brazilian Folk Rock that emerged in the 1970s, incorporating elements of Sertanejo, Country Rock, and MPB.

name: Funk Rock
description: Rock that incorporates prominent Funk grooves.

children.name: Funk Metal
children.description: Melds Funk Rock grooves with slap basslines and metallic guitarwork.

name: Garage Rock
description: Raw and energetic, generally employing simple, sloppy, and fuzzbox-distorted guitar melodies in addition to frequent shouting or screaming.

children.name: Freakbeat
children.description: Combined elements of British Rhythm & Blues, Beat Music, and Pop Rock with the studio effects of Psychedelia - fuzztones, flanging, chorus - to create a style often seen as a British relative of American Garage Rock and Psychedelic Rock.

children.name: Garage Punk
children.description: Combination of the raw fuzztones of the original Garage Rock bands of the 1960s with the tempo and attitude of Punk Rock.

children.name: Garage Rock Revival
children.description: Incorporated the raucous spirit of '60s Garage Rock into the sensibilities of Alternative Rock and Indie Rock; predominant in the '00s.

name: Glam Rock
description: Incorporates elements of Rock & Roll and Blues Rock into catchy Pop Rock melodies, usually accompanied with a strong sense of theatricality.

children.name: Glam Punk
children.description: Contrasts a snotty, nihilistic, and combative attitude of punk with theatrics and flamboyance.

name: Hardcore [Punk]
description: Broad genre which originated in the late 1970s; early work featured simple songs that took the punk formula and produced its most extreme result.

children.name: Beatdown Hardcore
children.description: Heavy, urban inspired and breakdown oriented with strong relations to Metalcore.

children.name: Easycore
children.description: Combines the pop choruses, high-pitched vocals, and playful nature of Pop Punk with heavy, metallic breakdowns and occasional unclean vocals akin to Metalcore and Post-Hardcore.

children.name: Electronicore
children.description: Infuses melodic aspects of Metalcore and Post-Hardcore with various styles of Electronic Dance Music.

children.name: Grindcore
children.description: Features shortened song structures and a diverse palette of intense techniques such as blast and skank beats, tremolo and down-picking, and various harsh vocal styles.

children.name: Cybergrind
children.description: Standard conventions of Grindcore taken to an even more discordant and rapid-fire extreme, with added Electronic dimensions of computer-generated noises and drum machines.

children.name: Deathgrind
children.description: Combines the intensity and high-pitched screams of Grindcore with the technicality and low guttural vocals of Death Metal.

children.name: Goregrind
children.description: Death Metal-influenced riffs with rhythms ranging from very fast to slower mid-tempos correlated with pitch-shifted vocals, sloppy playing and production, and gore-themed aesthetics.

children.name: Gorenoise
children.description: Combines and subverts Goregrind and Grindcore with brash Noise and even faster drum tempos.

children.name: Pornogrind
children.description: Groovy, mid-tempo style known for its exaggerated bouncy rhythm and common pornographic themes.

children.name: Mincecore
children.description: Raw and simplistic with heavy reliance on Punk structures while including political and socially aware themes.

children.name: Hardcore Punk
children.description: Emerged in the late 1970s, often featuring extensive use of yelling or screaming, a stripped-down production style, and very short songs.

children.name: Burning Spirits
children.description: Emphasis on delivering a very energetic and triumphant sound with flashy and soaring Metal solos, "melodramatic" or "uplifting" chord progressions, and singalong, over the top, harsh vocals.

children.name: Crossover Thrash
children.description: Fusion of Thrash Metal and Hardcore Punk which started in the 1980s.

children.name: Crust Punk
children.description: Metallic form of Hardcore Punk that grew out of the Anarcho-Punk movement in the mid-1980s.

children.name: Blackened Crust
children.description: Borrows heavily from Black Metal production, blast beats, tremolo guitar, and vocals, while retaining the core Crust Punk sound, lyrical themes, and aesthetic.

children.name: Neocrust
children.description: Melodic, dark, and atmospheric style that often incorporates influences from Sludge Metal, Post-Metal, Black Metal, and Screamo.

children.name: Stenchcore
children.description: Heavier, more metallic form of Crust Punk drawing influence from Thrash Metal as well as Death Metal and Heavy Metal.

children.name: D-Beat
children.description: Early 1980s Hardcore Punk featuring Metal influences and a distinct drum style also known as the D-beat.

children.name: Japanese Hardcore
children.description: Bands from Japan, performing styles such as Burning Spirits, Crust Punk, and Thrashcore.

children.name: Melodic Hardcore
children.description: Emerged in the USA in the early to mid-1980s, placing emphasis on melodic vocals and technical guitar riffs rather than raw aggression.

children.name: Mincecore
children.description: Raw and simplistic with heavy reliance on Punk structures while including political and socially aware themes.

children.name: New York Hardcore
children.description: Hardcore Punk bands from New York City from the 1980s and onwards.

children.name: Powerviolence
children.description: Originated in the late 1980s/early 1990s; takes the blueprints of Thrashcore and Grindcore, with the addition of wildly fluctuating tempos within a single song.

children.name: Skacore
children.description: Fuses skank rhythms and frantic blasts of horns with hardcore intensity.

children.name: Crack Rock Steady
children.description: Fuses Skacore with elements of Crust Punk and sometimes Metal; coupled with anti-establishment lyrics.

children.name: Street Punk
children.description: Driven by Oi! style group vocals, catchy melodies, and aggressive songwriting akin to Punk Rock of the 1970s fused with Hardcore Punk of the 1980s.

children.name: Thrashcore
children.description: Fast tempos, brief song structures, and the occasional use of blast beats.

children.name: UK82
children.description: UK scene that occurred during the early 1980s, consisting of developing hardcore styles such as early Street Punk and D-Beat bands.

children.name: Metalcore
children.description: Drop-tuned guitar riffs, constant double kick drumming with varying tempos and techniques, breakdown sections, and screaming or shouting vocals.

children.name: Deathcore
children.description: Fusion genre integrating elements from Death Metal, using harsh guttural vocals, blast beats, and palm-muted or tremolo-picked riffs in conjunction with breakdowns.

children.name: Mathcore
children.description: Rhythmically complex, features unconventional time signatures, syncopated and dissonant riffs and erratic metric shifts.

children.name: Melodic Metalcore
children.description: Originated in the late 1990s when some metalcore bands infused elements of Melodic Death Metal into their sound to create a more metallic and melodic style.

children.name: Nintendocore
children.description: Fuses Post-Hardcore and Metalcore influences with Chiptune instrumentation.

children.name: Noisecore
children.description: Short blasts of riff-less, Noise-driven music accompanied with chaotic drums and screamed vocals.

children.name: Post-Hardcore
children.description: Emerged in the mid-1980s from Hardcore Punk that expanded on its aggression and dynamics through longer and more complex arrangements.

children.name: Emocore
children.description: Emerged primarily in Washington D.C. in 1985 as a reaction to the stagnant Hardcore Punk scene, with a less aggressive style that was more melodic and often featured emotional, introspective lyrics.

children.name: Screamo
children.description: Began in the early 1990s, merging the emotional lyrics and melodicism of Emo with the intensity, aggression and speed of Hardcore Punk.

children.name: Emoviolence
children.description: Volatile, aggressive sound of Screamo with slight Powerviolence undertones.

children.name: Swancore
children.description: High-register clean vocals and technical instrumentation drawn from Math Rock and Progressive Rock.

children.name: Sasscore
children.description: Emerged in the early 2000s; characterized by sassy vocal styles and chaotic, erratic instrumentals.

name: Hard Rock
description: Heavier Rock originating in the mid-to-late 1960s from Psychedelic Rock and Blues Rock.

children.name: Glam Metal
children.description: Very catchy hooks and guitar riffs, sing-along choruses, and lyrics often glamorizing the "sex, drugs and rock & roll" lifestyle.

children.name: Heavy Psych
children.description: Developed in the late 1960s with influence from Blues Rock, such as heavy dependence on riffs and willingness to improvise, adding crushing levels of heaviness with thick fuzzy guitars to create a doomy and morose atmosphere.

children.name: Stoner Rock
children.description: Psychedelic timbres, raw production, and stylistic influence from Doom Metal and Heavy Psych.

name: Heartland Rock
description: Borrows elements from Folk Rock, Roots Rock, and 1950s-60s Rock & Roll; often characterized by its conscious, communal lyrical concerns and working-class appeal.

name: Industrial Rock
description: Incorporates abrasive guitars and synthesizers inspired by Industrial and various Post-Industrial styles.

name: Jam Band
description: Often performed in a live setting and combines diverse styles under the Rock umbrella as well as Funk, Jazz, Country and/or Blues.

children.name: Jamgrass
children.description: Emphasizes instrumental jamming and extended performances with many outside influences.

children.name: Livetronica
children.description: Incorporates Electronic instrumentation into live Rock jamming, drawing on a wide variety of Electronic Dance Music and Downtempo styles.

name: Jazz-Rock
description: Strongly influenced by Jazz in structure and/or instrumentation.

name: Latin Rock
description: Fusion of Rock, often Psychedelic Rock, with Latin American rhythms, especially Afro-Latin genres.

name: Manguebeat
description: Counterculture fusion of traditional Northeastern Brazilian Music genres with modern Rock and Hip Hop.

name: Math Rock
description: Typified by complex rhythmic patterns, angular chords and melodic structures, often featuring odd time signatures, resulting in a "mathematical" sound.

children.name: Math Pop
children.description: Energetic Indie Rock which incorporates poppier melodies and song structures into the unconventional rhythmic patterns of Math Rock.

name: Metal
description: Driving and distorted riffs, aggressive drumming, vigorous vocals, and an all-around show of brute force in its early days, since branching into dozens of subgenres.

children.name: Alternative Metal
children.description: Mid-tempo style emphasizing melodicism and rhythmic heaviness; branches outside of the stylistic conventions of Metal.

children.name: Funk Metal
children.description: Melds Funk Rock grooves with slap basslines and metallic guitarwork.

children.name: Neue Deutsche Härte
children.description: Alternative Metal and Industrial Metal that incorporates various aspects of electronic music, specifically Electronic Dance Music.

children.name: Nu Metal
children.description: Emphasizes rhythm, using elements of Funk Metal and Hip Hop to create a cleaner, more groove-oriented sound.

children.name: Rap Metal
children.description: Features rapped vocals, typically formed around heavy, mid-tempo, and groove-oriented playing in addition to elements of Hip Hop beats such as record scratching.

children.name: Avant-Garde Metal
children.description: Often breaking the bounds of the genre through experimental structures and instrumentation, or by incorporating outside influences.

children.name: Black Metal
children.description: Typified by highly distorted, trebly, tremolo-picked guitars, blast beats, double kick drumming, shrieked vocals, and raw, underproduced sound that often favors atmosphere over technical skills and melody.

children.name: Atmospheric Black Metal
children.description: Focuses on the atmospheric element using slowly developing riffs, repetitive melodies, usually slow to medium tempos, and commonly synthesized ambient textures.

children.name: Blackgaze
children.description: Melds tremolo-picked riffing, high-gain guitars, and harsh, often wailing, vocals with mellow, dreamy textures and melodic song structures.

children.name: Black 'n' Roll
children.description: Incorporates elements of Hard Rock, Glam Rock, and Heavy Metal.

children.name: Black Noise
children.description: Incorporates unconventional sounds with overpowering or constant Noise and Black Metal elements, often being heavily texture-oriented, abrasive, dissonant, atonal, or repetitive.

children.name: Depressive Black Metal
children.description: Characterized by lethargic atmospheres; usually repetitive song structures and slow-mid tempos; high-pitched wailing and gruff vocals; and usage of non-distorted instruments like keyboards and acoustic guitars.

children.name: Melodic Black Metal
children.description: Cleaner production, more diverse arrangements, and a stronger emphasis on melody than is typical for Black Metal.

children.name: Pagan Black Metal
children.description: Incorporates acoustic guitar and traditional instrument passages, cleanly sung vocals, folk songs' melodies, and paganistic themes.

children.name: Symphonic Black Metal
children.description: Symphonic soundscapes, typically but not always synthesized.

children.name: War Metal
children.description: Aggressive, chaotic, and heavily Death Metal-influenced.

children.name: Death Metal
children.description: Features distorted, commonly down-tuned guitars; palm-muted and tremolo-picked riffs; aggressive, double-kicked percussion that utilizes various blast beats techniques; abrupt changes in tempo and time signatures; and guttural vocal styles.

children.name: Brutal Death Metal
children.description: Emphasizes abrasiveness, chunky rhythmic atonal riffs, and low guttural vocals.

children.name: Slam Death Metal
children.description: Focuses on slow or midtempo (as well as breakdown-style) sections built on chromatic, palm-muted riffs - so-called "slams".

children.name: Death 'n' Roll
children.description: Incorporates elements of Hard Rock, Heavy Metal, and Blues Rock while retaining the typical heavily distorted rhythm guitars and gruff vocals.

children.name: Deathgrind
children.description: Combines the intensity and high-pitched screams of Grindcore with the technicality and low guttural vocals of Death Metal.

children.name: Melodic Death Metal
children.description: Utilizes the guitar harmonies and melodic sound of Heavy Metal, while keeping the main characteristics of Death Metal.

children.name: Technical Death Metal
children.description: Focuses on challenging, demanding songwriting and instrumental skill.

children.name: Dissonant Death Metal
children.description: Emphasizes discordant, dense songwriting and utilizes pinch harmonics, scratchy guitar leads, and atonality.

children.name: Doom Metal
children.description: Plodding tempos, repeated chords, and thick, distorted, down-tuned guitars in a style focused on foreboding, atmosphere, and tension.

children.name: Death Doom Metal
children.description: Fuses down-tuned guitars, growled vocals, and aggressive, often double-kick drumming with a mournful, somber atmosphere and plodding tempos.

children.name: Funeral Doom Metal
children.description: Features exceptionally slow, funeral dirge-like tempos, heavily distorted, sluggish guitars, mournful atmosphere, and distant, hushed growls and grunts.

children.name: Traditional Doom Metal
children.description: Monotonous and heavy playing style; repetitive, rough, and sometimes atonal guitar riffs; a "rocking to sleep" bass; and influences from both Blues Rock and Psychedelic Rock.

children.name: Epic Doom Metal
children.description: Emphasizes Heavy Metal influence and theatrical vocals.

children.name: Drone Metal
children.description: Composed with heavy repetitive drones, minimalist structure, and slow tempos.

children.name: Folk Metal
children.description: Features influences from various types of Traditional Folk Music expressed through melodies and/or traditional instrumentation, notably having a large scene in Europe.

children.name: Celtic Metal
children.description: Features Celtic Folk Music elements.

children.name: Mittelalter-Metal
children.description: Emerged as a metallic style in the mid-to-late 1990s from the German Neo-Medieval movement.

children.name: Gothic Metal
children.description: Features heavy, low-mid tempo riffs, somber, gloomy atmosphere accentuated by ethereal keyboards and synthesizer layers, and vocal styles ranging from raspy growls to female operatic singing.

children.name: Grindcore
children.description: Features shortened song structures and a diverse palette of intense techniques such as blast and skank beats, tremolo and down-picking, and various harsh vocal styles.

children.name: Cybergrind
children.description: Standard conventions of Grindcore taken to an even more discordant and rapid-fire extreme, with added Electronic dimensions of computer-generated noises and drum machines.

children.name: Deathgrind
children.description: Combines the intensity and high-pitched screams of Grindcore with the technicality and low guttural vocals of Death Metal.

children.name: Goregrind
children.description: Death Metal-influenced riffs with rhythms ranging from very fast to slower mid-tempos correlated with pitch-shifted vocals, sloppy playing and production, and gore-themed aesthetics.

children.name: Gorenoise
children.description: Combines and subverts Goregrind and Grindcore with brash Noise and even faster drum tempos.

children.name: Pornogrind
children.description: Groovy, mid-tempo style known for its exaggerated bouncy rhythm and common pornographic themes.

children.name: Mincecore
children.description: Raw and simplistic with heavy reliance on Punk structures while including political and socially aware themes.

children.name: Groove Metal
children.description: Midtempo riffs influenced by Thrash Metal but with a greater focus on rhythmic syncopation and heaviness over speed.

children.name: Heavy Metal
children.description: Heavier outgrowth of Hard Rock featuring greater distortion and intensity along with lesser Blues influences.

children.name: NWOBHM
children.description: Acronym for new wave of British Heavy Metal, which occurred in the late 1970s, taking some influence from Punk Rock.

children.name: Speed Metal
children.description: Originating from the NWOBHM and influenced by the work of early heavy metal bands, being faster and somewhat more aggressive than heavy metal.

children.name: US Power Metal
children.description: American style influenced by NWOBHM that features heavily distorted guitars paired with more aggressive riffs, mid-tempo Heavy Metal rhythms, and over-the-top theatrical vocals with fantasy or conceptual themes.

children.name: Industrial Metal
children.description: Incorporates the abrasive and heavy sound from Industrial into a Metal context by using elements from Post-Industrial like synthesizers and drum machines.

children.name: Cyber Metal
children.description: Originated around 1999, influenced by EBM and Aggrotech with more melodic and less repetitive riffs as well as harsh vocals.

children.name: Neue Deutsche Härte
children.description: Alternative Metal and Industrial Metal that incorporates various aspects of electronic music, specifically Electronic Dance Music.

children.name: Kawaii Metal
children.description: Combines a heavy and metallic style with an upbeat, J-Pop-indebted tone and vocal style; associated with a "kawaii" aesthetic.

children.name: Metalcore
children.description: Drop-tuned guitar riffs, constant double kick drumming with varying tempos and techniques, breakdown sections, and screaming or shouting vocals.

children.name: Deathcore
children.description: Fusion genre integrating elements from Death Metal, using harsh guttural vocals, blast beats, and palm-muted or tremolo-picked riffs in conjunction with breakdowns.

children.name: Mathcore
children.description: Rhythmically complex, features unconventional time signatures, syncopated and dissonant riffs and erratic metric shifts.

children.name: Melodic Metalcore
children.description: Originated in the late 1990s when some metalcore bands infused elements of Melodic Death Metal into their sound to create a more metallic and melodic style.

children.name: Neoclassical Metal
children.description: Greatly influenced by Western Classical Music in its style of playing and composing.

children.name: Post-Metal
children.description: Heavily utilizes timbre and texture to have enormous song build-ups and huge atmosphere.

children.name: Atmospheric Sludge Metal
children.description: Combines slow, churning guitar riffs and thunderous percussion with dark, extensive otherworldly sonic landscapes.

children.name: Doomgaze
children.description: Gloomy and somber atmosphere, amplified by the slow tempo and gloominess of Doom Metal, combined with the effects, washes of sound, and vocals found within Shoegaze.

children.name: Power Metal
children.description: Developed from Heavy Metal and Speed Metal; characterized by its emphasis on speed, vocal melody and harmonized lead guitars.

children.name: Progressive Metal
children.description: Fuses amplified, guitar-driven sound with technical proficiency, virtuosity, complex compositions, innovative arrangements, eclecticism, and additional instrumentation.

children.name: Djent
children.description: Syncopated rhythmic structures, angular melodies, and dissonant chords.

children.name: Sludge Metal
children.description: Combines the slow, dark instrumentals and atmosphere of Doom Metal with the aggressive, harsh screams and shouts credited to Hardcore Punk.

children.name: Atmospheric Sludge Metal
children.description: Combines slow, churning guitar riffs and thunderous percussion with dark, extensive otherworldly sonic landscapes.

children.name: Southern Metal
children.description: Blues-influenced style that primarily incorporates Sludge Metal and Stoner Metal with metallic Southern Rock riffs.

children.name: Stenchcore
children.description: Heavier, more metallic form of Crust Punk drawing influence from Thrash Metal as well as Death Metal and Heavy Metal.

children.name: Stoner Metal
children.description: Combines elements of Doom Metal with elements of Psychedelic Rock and Blues Rock to create a melodic yet heavy sound.

children.name: Symphonic Metal
children.description: Elements of symphonic and orchestral music.

children.name: Thrash Metal
children.description: Features fast tempos; rhythmically focused, frequently palm-muted riffs; shredding solos; aggressive, often double-kicked drumming; skank beats; and vocal styles ranging from shouts to melodic singing.

children.name: Crossover Thrash
children.description: Fusion of Thrash Metal and Hardcore Punk which started in the 1980s.

children.name: Technical Thrash Metal
children.description: Places great emphasis on complex songwriting and demanding instrumental parts.

children.name: Trance Metal
children.description: Tempo between 130 and 160 BPM, played with keyboards and metal instrumentation, sung with harsh and aggressive vocals including many clean melodic styles; regularly uses elements of Melodic Death Metal, Symphonic Metal, and Electronic Dance Music.

children.name: Viking Metal
children.description: Developed out of Black Metal and embodies an epic, Viking-like aesthetic.

name: Miejski folk
description: Alternative and Punk music influenced by Folklor miejski and Contemporary Folk.

name: Mod
description: 1960s youth subculture in the United Kingdom, drawing from British Rhythm & Blues, Beat Music, Garage Rock, and Pop sensibilities alongside a distinctive fashion style.

children.name: Mod Revival
children.description: Late 1970s and early 1980s revival of Mod fashion and music, featuring influence from the nascent Punk Rock scene.

name: New Wave
description: Agitated and busy guitar melodies, jerky rhythms, often a heavy reliance on synthesizers, and typically intricate percussive sections, closely related to Post-Punk and influenced by Pop Rock and Electronic.

children.name: Neue Deutsche Welle
children.description: German genre primarily associated with New Wave; influenced by Punk Rock, Post-Punk, Synthpop, Synth Punk, and Industrial.

children.name: New Romantic
children.description: UK pop cultural movement associated with the early 1980s and defined by a distinct, flamboyant fashion sense.

name: Noise Rock
description: Incorporates high amounts of distortion and varying levels of dissonance, lo-fi production, and feedback.

children.name: Shitgaze
children.description: Extremely raw and lo-fi, blending raucous Garage Rock with the abrasive, often dissonant guitars of Noise Rock to create a sonic wall of deafening distortion inspired by Shoegaze.

name: Pop Rock
description: Standard verse-chorus Pop that can also be categorized under Rock for its use of guitars, drums, and propulsive rhythms.

children.name: Beat Music
children.description: Emerged in the early 1960s in the United Kingdom, drawing on Rock & Roll and the late 1950s Skiffle revival.

children.name: Freakbeat
children.description: Combined elements of British Rhythm & Blues, Beat Music, and Pop Rock with the studio effects of Psychedelia - fuzztones, flanging, chorus - to create a style often seen as a British relative of American Garage Rock and Psychedelic Rock.

children.name: Group Sounds
children.description: Japanese bands in the mid-to-late 1960s who began performing a style of Beat Music primarily in English.

children.name: Jovem Guarda
children.description: 1960s Brazilian youth-oriented Pop Rock, with romantic lyrics and influenced by Merseybeat and Rockabilly.

children.name: Merseybeat
children.description: Light, highly melodic style of Beat Music popular in the UK during the early 1960s, named due to the abundance of bands from Liverpool beside the River Mersey.

children.name: Nederbeat
children.description: Dutch answer to the UK Beat Music boom of the 1960s.

children.name: Big Music
children.description: Rooted in Post-Punk and popular in the 1980s, with anthemic songwriting and a grandiose, stadium-ready sound.

children.name: Britpop
children.description: Emerged in the United Kingdom in the early 1990s, with a style hearkening back to the traditional guitar-driven songs and melodic hooks found in the British Pop Rock of the 1960s.

children.name: Jangle Pop
children.description: Pop-oriented songwriting based around chiming jangly guitar lines, and propulsive rhythms often drawn from Post-Punk.

children.name: C86
children.description: Distinctly ramshackle, often Twee Pop-infused combination of British Indie Rock and Jangle Pop.

children.name: Neo-Acoustic
children.description: Japanese term for a cross-section of Indie Pop and Jangle Pop with more prominent acoustic instrumentation and songwriting/arrangements that draw from Sophisti-Pop.

children.name: Paisley Underground
children.description: Emerged in Los Angeles in the early 1980s, featuring the energy of Power Pop and New Wave adorned with retro Psychedelia.

children.name: Manila Sound
children.description: Philippine Pop Rock movement most prominent in the 1970s; served as a predecessor of OPM.

children.name: Piano Rock
children.description: Based around the piano, as opposed to most traditional Rock, which is based around the guitar.

children.name: Post-Britpop
children.description: Emerged in the late 1990s as a Britpop expansion mainly characterized by acoustic-leaning instrumentation, lush string arrangements, and mid-tempo song structures, as well as less apparent lyrical concerns for Britain in favor of introspective, contemplative themes.

children.name: Power Pop
children.description: Heavier Pop Rock that combines strong Pop melodies with loud power chords, characterized by prominent electric guitars, clear vocals, crisp harmonies, and economical arrangements.

children.name: Soft Rock
children.description: Light, melodic, radio-friendly Rock which gained huge commercial success in the 1970s.

children.name: Tropical Rock
children.description: Combines influences from Country Rock and Caribbean Music to create an acoustic and breezy "island" themed sound.

children.name: Yacht Rock
children.description: Slick Pop Rock influenced by smoother R&B styles, popular in the late 1970s and often associated with California.

children.name: Sonido Donosti
children.description: Sentimental and melancholic scene, influenced by Twee Pop, that emerged in the late 1980s in Donostia / San Sebastián, Spain.

children.name: Stereo
children.description: Burmese Pop Rock genre which emerged in the mid-1960s.

children.name: Twee Pop
children.description: Distinct Post-Punk background and often jangling guitars, defined by a cute aesthetic and lyrics combined with an indie/DIY attitude and a simplicity often indebted to Punk Rock.

children.name: Vocal Surf
children.description: Appropriates the sounds of instrumental Surf Rock, combining surfing- and car-themed lyrics with a style that draws primarily from Doo-Wop and Rock & Roll.

name: Post-Punk
description: Emerged alongside the initial Punk Rock explosion in the mid-to-late 1970s, putting a greater emphasis on frequent experimentation, atmosphere, generally stripped-back instrumentation and, at times, angular-sounding guitars, throbbing bass lines, and interlocked drumming.

children.name: Coldwave
children.description: Originated in Europe in the late 1970s and early 1980s and is known for its generally dark, gloomy atmosphere and heavy reliance on synthesizers.

children.name: Dance-Punk
children.description: Mixes the energy of Punk Rock with the danceable rhythms of Funk and Disco.

children.name: Gothic Rock
children.description: Dark atmosphere and gothic imagery, featuring synthesizers and moderate use of chorus and echo effects.

children.name: Deathrock
children.description: More Punk-oriented offshoot of Gothic Rock that emphasizes energy and an effect-laden sound over pure atmosphere.

children.name: No Wave
children.description: Emerged in New York City during the late 1970s; took the ethos of Punk Rock but discarded melody and catchiness, including instead extreme noise, distortion, feedback, angular rhythms, stream-of-consciousness lyrics, and more.

children.name: Post-Punk Revival
children.description: Incorporating the sounds and aesthetics of Post-Punk into Indie Rock, with jagged guitarwork, a dominant and danceable rhythm section, clean production, and poppy song structures.

name: Post-Rock
description: Emphasis on timbre, texture, and atmosphere over traditional conventions while often embracing influences from genres not usually associated with Rock.

name: Progressive Rock
description: Associated with complex harmonies, instrumental virtuosity, and usually multi-section song structures featuring broader instrumentation compared to other Rock styles.

children.name: Avant-Prog
children.description: Focuses on highly complex, dense arrangements often featuring high amounts of dissonance and uncommon time signatures, sometimes extending towards atonality, free time, Free Improvisation, and other avant-garde techniques.

children.name: Brutal Prog
children.description: Characterized by highly intense and visceral songwriting, usually featuring substantial reliance on dissonance, odd time signatures, blistering tempos, angular and mercurial rhythms, and Punk's DIY attitude.

children.name: Rock in Opposition
children.description: European, complex Avant-Prog from the 1970s, so named due to the artists' opposition to the music industry.

children.name: Zeuhl
children.description: Epic, operatic sound fusing Jazz, Progressive Rock and Modern Classical music.

children.name: Canterbury Scene
children.description: Offshoot of Progressive Rock developed in the counterculture of the English city of Canterbury in the late 1960s, emphasizing the influence of Jazz-Rock and Jazz Fusion.

children.name: Neo-Prog
children.description: Synthesizer-driven style of Progressive Rock that emerged in the early 1980s in the United Kingdom.

children.name: Symphonic Prog
children.description: Incorporates Classical Music elements that can manifest in longer form works that deviate from traditional popular song structures, and the use of lush keyboards to replicate Orchestral textures.

name: Proto-Punk
description: Used to describe what influenced or in some way resembled Punk Rock before that genre's commercial breakthrough in 1976.

name: Psychedelic Rock
description: Rock which emerged in the mid-1960s that often attempts to emulate or enhance the effects of psychedelic drugs.

children.name: Acid Rock
children.description: Heavier with an emphasis on instrumental jamming and "wah" guitar effects.

children.name: Heavy Psych
children.description: Developed in the late 1960s with influence from Blues Rock, such as heavy dependence on riffs and willingness to improvise, adding crushing levels of heaviness with thick fuzzy guitars to create a doomy and morose atmosphere.

children.name: Raga Rock
children.description: Influenced by South Asian Music, featuring a droning compositional quality and commonly incorporating instruments like sitar, tambura, and tablas.

children.name: Space Rock
children.description: Heavy use of synthesizers and guitar effects to create dense atmospheric soundscapes intended to evoke images of outer space and science fiction scenarios.

children.name: Space Rock Revival
children.description: Type of Neo-Psychedelia that draws from the aesthetics and expansive sonic palette of Space Rock combined with the more minimal, back-to-basics approach of the Post-Punk era.

children.name: Zamrock
children.description: Zambian 1970s Psychedelic Rock found mainly throughout the Copperbelt region.

name: Pub Rock
description: Rock that developed in the United Kingdom in the early to mid-1970s mainly as a reaction to the perceived excess and pretension of the Progressive Rock and Glam Rock genres.

name: Punk Blues
description: Fusion of the instrumentation and scales of Blues Rock with Punk.

name: Punk Rock
description: Fast tempos, loud and distorted riffs, simple songs, frequent use of power chords, and shouted vocals, originating in the mid-1970s in response to commercial, sentimental, and complex Rock.

children.name: Anarcho-Punk
children.description: In part a reaction to the commercial breakthrough of Punk Rock in the late 1970s, with some artists adopting an intentionally rougher and sloppier sound combined with lyrical themes of anarchism and related issues that gave the genre its name.

children.name: Celtic Punk
children.description: Infuses the sounds of Celtic Folk Music into Punk Rock.

children.name: Deathrock
children.description: More Punk-oriented offshoot of Gothic Rock that emphasizes energy and an effect-laden sound over pure atmosphere.

children.name: Deutschpunk
children.description: Partly a reaction to the commercialization of the German movement Neue Deutsche Welle; characterized by extreme speed, consciously basic songwriting, crude musicianship, and radical leftism.

children.name: Garage Punk
children.description: Combination of the raw fuzztones of the original Garage Rock bands of the 1960s with the tempo and attitude of Punk Rock.

children.name: Glam Punk
children.description: Contrasts a snotty, nihilistic, and combative attitude of punk with theatrics and flamboyance.

children.name: Hardcore Punk
children.description: Emerged in the late 1970s, often featuring extensive use of yelling or screaming, a stripped-down production style, and very short songs.

children.name: Burning Spirits
children.description: Emphasis on delivering a very energetic and triumphant sound with flashy and soaring Metal solos, "melodramatic" or "uplifting" chord progressions, and singalong, over the top, harsh vocals.

children.name: Crossover Thrash
children.description: Fusion of Thrash Metal and Hardcore Punk which started in the 1980s.

children.name: Crust Punk
children.description: Metallic form of Hardcore Punk that grew out of the Anarcho-Punk movement in the mid-1980s.

children.name: Blackened Crust
children.description: Borrows heavily from Black Metal production, blast beats, tremolo guitar, and vocals, while retaining the core Crust Punk sound, lyrical themes, and aesthetic.

children.name: Neocrust
children.description: Melodic, dark, and atmospheric style that often incorporates influences from Sludge Metal, Post-Metal, Black Metal, and Screamo.

children.name: Stenchcore
children.description: Heavier, more metallic form of Crust Punk drawing influence from Thrash Metal as well as Death Metal and Heavy Metal.

children.name: D-Beat
children.description: Early 1980s Hardcore Punk featuring Metal influences and a distinct drum style also known as the D-beat.

children.name: Japanese Hardcore
children.description: Bands from Japan, performing styles such as Burning Spirits, Crust Punk, and Thrashcore.

children.name: Melodic Hardcore
children.description: Emerged in the USA in the early to mid-1980s, placing emphasis on melodic vocals and technical guitar riffs rather than raw aggression.

children.name: Mincecore
children.description: Raw and simplistic with heavy reliance on Punk structures while including political and socially aware themes.

children.name: New York Hardcore
children.description: Hardcore Punk bands from New York City from the 1980s and onwards.

children.name: Powerviolence
children.description: Originated in the late 1980s/early 1990s; takes the blueprints of Thrashcore and Grindcore, with the addition of wildly fluctuating tempos within a single song.

children.name: Skacore
children.description: Fuses skank rhythms and frantic blasts of horns with hardcore intensity.

children.name: Crack Rock Steady
children.description: Fuses Skacore with elements of Crust Punk and sometimes Metal; coupled with anti-establishment lyrics.

children.name: Street Punk
children.description: Driven by Oi! style group vocals, catchy melodies, and aggressive songwriting akin to Punk Rock of the 1970s fused with Hardcore Punk of the 1980s.

children.name: Thrashcore
children.description: Fast tempos, brief song structures, and the occasional use of blast beats.

children.name: UK82
children.description: UK scene that occurred during the early 1980s, consisting of developing hardcore styles such as early Street Punk and D-Beat bands.

children.name: Horror Punk
children.description: Horror movie-themed genre of Punk Rock.

children.name: Könsrock
children.description: Inspired by Post-Punk but with a more bizarre atmosphere with unusual or comic vocal techniques and a lyrical focus on the offensive and scatological.

children.name: Oi!
children.description: Rejection to burgeoning Art Punk; a much simpler and more melodic style.

children.name: Pop Punk
children.description: Blends the loud, fast-paced, and sometimes sloppy sound of Punk Rock with the catchy sound and songwriting of Pop.

children.name: Easycore
children.description: Combines the pop choruses, high-pitched vocals, and playful nature of Pop Punk with heavy, metallic breakdowns and occasional unclean vocals akin to Metalcore and Post-Hardcore.

children.name: Seishun Punk
children.description: Short-lived Japanese style popular in the early 2000s, characterized by a raw and abrasive style, Folk-inspired songwriting, and youth-oriented straightforward lyrics.

children.name: Psychobilly
children.description: Cross-pollination of Punk Rock and Rockabilly.

children.name: Queercore
children.description: Movement mainly distinguished by its lyrical content expressing the viewpoints of the LGBTQ+ community, as well as promoting queer pride and unity.

children.name: Riot Grrrl
children.description: Underground feminist Punk Rock movement and related scene(s) which emerged in the United States in the early 1990s.

children.name: Ska Punk
children.description: Characterized by up-tempo skank rhythms, catchy horn sections, and spirited guitar work; delivered with a fun and rebellious energy.

children.name: Skacore
children.description: Fuses skank rhythms and frantic blasts of horns with hardcore intensity.

children.name: Crack Rock Steady
children.description: Fuses Skacore with elements of Crust Punk and sometimes Metal; coupled with anti-establishment lyrics.

children.name: Skate Punk
children.description: Combines the speed of Melodic Hardcore with the catchiness of Pop Punk, finding a middle ground between the two.

children.name: Surf Punk
children.description: Punk Rock that incorporates elements of Surf Rock.

children.name: Vikingarock
children.description: Incorporates influences from Nordic Folk Music and the imagery of Viking romanticism and Norse mythology.

name: Rap Rock
description: Fusion of Hip Hop and Rock, often featuring the former’s rhythmic vocal delivery and the latter’s heavy, distorted instrumentation.

children.name: Rap Metal
children.description: Features rapped vocals, typically formed around heavy, mid-tempo, and groove-oriented playing in addition to elements of Hip Hop beats such as record scratching.

name: Reggae Rock
description: Incorporates the offbeat rhythms and staccato "skank" guitar of Reggae.

name: Rock & Roll
description: Developed in the United States and popularized in the 1950s, featuring prominent Blues scales, poppy structures, and strong rhythms.

children.name: Indorock
children.description: Originated in the Netherlands in the 1950s, with Dutch-Indonesian musicians incorporating traditional Indonesian influences.

children.name: Rockabilly
children.description: Driving guitars, frantic vocals, and slap-back echo in the bass.

children.name: Psychobilly
children.description: Cross-pollination of Punk Rock and Rockabilly.

children.name: Twist
children.description: Simple, fast, and energetic dance popular in the early 1960s.

name: Rock andaluz
description: Emerged during the mid-1970s in Spain; primarily utilizes Flamenco and often Symphonic Prog elements.

name: Rock andino
description: Emerged in the Andean countries in the late 1960s and early 1970s, incorporating traditional instruments and harmonies from Indigenous Andean Music within a Rock format.

name: Rock Musical
description: Style of musical theatre inspired by Rock.

name: Rock Opera
description: Hybrid of rock and, sometimes, musical theatre stylings with heavily rock-tinged songs combining to tell a coherent story.

name: Rock urbano español
description: Spanish scene originating in the mid-to-late 1970s that gained dominance with the end of the Francoist dictatorship and the end of censorship around lyrical topics like social issues.

name: Roots Rock
description: Consciously and predominantly incorporates elements of its predecessors and original roots such as Country, Blues, Rhythm & Blues, Rock & Roll, and American Folk Music, but also many other American traditions.

children.name: Swamp Rock
children.description: Intermixture of Zydeco, Cajun Music, New Orleans Blues, and Pop under the roof of Rock.

children.name: Tex-Mex
children.description: Mixes Rock & Roll, Blues, Country, and several types of Hispanic American Music, particularly Tejano Music.

name: Southern Rock
description: Emerged from the American South in the early 1970s, blending Blues Rock, Hard Rock, and Rock & Roll with elements of Country and Contemporary Folk.

name: Sufi Rock
description: Pakistani subgenre rooted in Sufi tradition, featuring South Asian instruments like the dhol, tabla, and sitar within a Rock band format with lyrics and imagery inspired by traditional Sufi poets.

name: Surf Music
description: Evolved from late 1950s instrumental Rock & Roll in the USA, particularly associated with the surfing culture in Southern California.

children.name: Indie Surf
children.description: Reverb-drenched, nostalgic, and often lo-fi, with influences from Surf Rock and Vocal Surf; rose to popularity around 2009.

children.name: Surf Punk
children.description: Punk Rock that incorporates elements of Surf Rock.

children.name: Surf Rock
children.description: Short instrumental songs with Rock & Roll rhythms overlaid with cheerful melodies played on reverb-drenched tremolo guitar.

children.name: Eleki
children.description: Japanese Surf Rock that emerged during the early to mid-1960s incorporating the use of pentatonic scales, traditional instrumentation, and covers of folk songs.

children.name: Rautalanka
children.description: Finnish guitar style mainly influenced by Rock & Roll, Surf Rock, and traditional European/Nordic Schlager.

children.name: Wong shadow
children.description: Small, short-lived guitar Pop movement in Thailand in the 1960s, fusing Surf Rock  with local melodies.

children.name: Vocal Surf
children.description: Appropriates the sounds of instrumental Surf Rock, combining surfing- and car-themed lyrics with a style that draws primarily from Doo-Wop and Rock & Roll.

name: Symphonic Rock
description: Incorporates elements resembling symphonic and orchestral music.

name: Tolai Rock
description: Fuses the music of the Tolai people of Papua New Guinea with Rock.

name: Zolo
description: Retrospective term grouping artists that fuse elements of New Wave and Progressive Rock with a flamboyant, quirky aesthetic and often the energy of Punk.
